title: We owe you an explanation... Our Ryzen 7950X3D Review is Late but Worth the Wait
tags: why didn't ltt post a review?

I know that's a pretty cynical take, but the truth is we have seen this strategy before. And aside from the crashing, our performance numbers were at least close enough to AMD's expectations, that even they initially told us, "Yep, everything looks fine." But here's the thing, silicon is notoriously fickle, especially with these bleeding edge process nodes. And good or bad might not be as binary as you might think. For any given wafer fresh off the production line, there are going to be multiple unusable dies. It's just the way it is. Now these kinds of defects are normal and these flawed lower performing processor dies are often used in lower end products, which is fine, except that from time to time a chip can be so marginal that it barely passes those usual quality control checks and then ends up falling short in the field. This is what we call losing the silicon lottery. Winning the silicon lottery on the other hand isn't simply getting a working chip, it's having an exceptional one. Like, are AMD's yields bad? Are we so unlucky as to get two poor performers in a row? Or is our testing methodology out of whack somehow? When we ran our original tests, we made sure to use AMD's recommended settings with fresh Windows installs, and most importantly, fresh chipset driver installs. That last part is much more important than usual, because the pre-release chipset driver only installs the new performance optimizer and the awkwardly named PPM Provisioning File driver when it detects a dual die X3D processor like the 7950X3D or 7900X3D. The release driver might behave the same way by the way. So if you buy one of these as an upgrade, double check to be sure. We're gonna have purchase links down below. These two tools are essential for getting the best performance out of these chips, because only one of its two dies has 3D V-Cache and runs at a lower clock speed while the other is a standard cache die that's optimized for higher clock speeds. Performance optimizer then automatically promotes the appropriate die's cores as the preferred cores in Windows' scheduler. While the PPM Provisioning File driver parks or puts to sleep the cores on the unused die. Games will then, assuming everything's working properly, typically get sent to the 3D V-Cache die for best performance. And as far as we can tell, this is down to a simple integration with Windows game mode and Xbox Game Bar rather than any special sauce that's been cooked up by AMD themselves. An important thing to note though, the driver does not disable the other die entirely and if enough threads are needed, it will wake them up even if you're in game. So it's worth noting that a 7900 X3D would wake up more often, since each die has only six cores instead of eight. Unsurprisingly then, if these features aren't working properly, the Window scheduler is just flying blind unaware of the differences between the two processor dies, and it'll end up ranking the best cores based on the fastest available across the whole CPU. Something it can't rightly determine. This can lead to situations where an app might run across multiple dies at once, despite only needing one die's worth of CPU threads, which can incur a latency penalty since the dies will have to transfer data from cache to cache rather than accessing it directly. Now, we confirmed that ours is definitely working correctly by comparing our data running stock versus having only one die manually enabled in the BIOS. Mind boggling even. Under a full Prime95 load, the 13900K consistently pulls over 320 watts, with the 7950X3D at less than half of that. But as it turns out, the dual die X3D chips work differently from most other CPUs. And it looks like the cores will aggressively try to clock down or even sleep whenever possible when they're not fully loaded. And that would explain what we observed with our GPU-bound scenario and with our 1440p results. It would also explain where some of that lost TDP went. Our best guess here is that AMD is airing on the side of caution when it comes to their X3D chips in order to keep them from redlining, thanks to the 3D V-Cache being much more sensitive to voltage and to heat than a typical Ryzen die. This behavior of course means that there is some performance being left on the table, and we can actually see some of that being clawed back with Ryzen Master's curve tuner function. While it isn't the fully unlocked overclocking that we were promised for X3D going forward, it does do a decent job of undervolting the chip, allowing it to push higher frequencies more often. The performance difference isn't night and day, but you are more likely to see that performance leadership that AMD is after, assuming that your sample is more golden than yellow, if you enable this function.
